Text Encoding Initiative

Version numbering of TEI Guidelines

1. When

2. What

3. Examples

 Use of Version number of TEI Guidelines

During its conference call of 27 Jan 04 the TEI Council agreed that:

  • conformant documents should specify the version of the TEI to which they conform by means of an attribute named version
  • its value should follow the pattern major.minor.micro, with numeric values.
  • guidelines on version numbering should be agreed by the editors and documented ASAP

../Council/tcm09.html#id2633880 This working paper proposes guidelines for version numbering of the Guidelines.

1. When

The version number should be updated whenever a user-visible change is made to the content of the Guidelines, whether that change is due to a change to the source ODD files or to a change in the stylesheets that produce the human-readable Guidelines or schemas.

But perhaps more useful than discussing when the version number is updated is to mention when it is not updated. The version number should not be updated when a change is made to the stylesheets that produce the Guidelines or schema from the source ODDs that changes only format, not content. Furthermore changes to Roma or other software that assist TEI users should not cause a change in the version number of the Guidelines.

So the following changes should not result in an updated version number:

  • a change to the stylesheets that changed the presentation of attribute values from fixed font to bold;
  • a correction of a typo in the <teiHeader> of the ODD source of the Guidelines. (Lou — do we like this corollary? — sb)
  • a bug fix to Roma which corrected a problem that caused incorrect DTD fragments to be generated if the additional tag-set for names & dates was selected

2. What

The version number will be a `dotted triad' in the form ‘major.minor.micro’. Each of major, minor, and micro is an integer. (I.e., as is common with such version numbering systems, leading zeroes may have to be inserted before string comparison can usefully be performed.)

The three components are updated as follows.

  • micro gets incremented whenever there is a user-visible content change that:
    • does not alter the set of documents that conform to the Guidelines (i.e., makes no syntactic change to the constraints prescribed), or
    • does not alter the intended set of documents that conform to the Guidelines, but rather only changes the set that actually do conform by correcting an error; and
    • does not significantly alter the semantics of conforming documents, or
    • alters the semantics of conforming documents by correcting an error.
  • minor gets incremented whenever there is a user-visible change that is not a large enough change to alter the existing chapter numbering, which changes the syntax or semantics of conforming documents other than minor error correction. When minor is incremented, micro is set to zero.
  • major gets incremented for major revisions of the Guidelines. At such increments chapter numbering, syntax specifications, etc. may change in significant ways. Major changes are not necessarily backwards compatible. When major is incremented both minor and micro are set to zero.

3. Examples

change to Guidelines or stylesheets change to version number
Correct typo in <teiHeader> none
Correct typo in <text> of Guidelines increment micro
Change stylesheet so that section headings are larger in the PDF version and centered in the HTML version none
Fix stylesheet so that the list of elements in the ‘may occur within’ listings in reference section are sorted by class, not just alphabetically increment micro
Fix stylesheet so that a newline is inserted between each set of elements in a given class in the ‘may occur within’ listings in reference section none
Correct the name of the referencesystem class to referenceSystem increment micro
After much discussion on TEI-L, change the largest <divN> from 7 to 9 increment minor
Add a new section at the end of the feature structure chapter with a few examples of using FSs to encode meta information about dying languages increment minor
After receiving a complaint that a particular example was offensive, change to a different example increment micro
Add a new chapter on the encoding of legal documents increment major
